description: The Republic of South Africa enforces anti-disinformation measures relating to the COVID-19 Pandemic in the Government Gazette on March 18, 2020. Any persons who publishes "any statement through any medium, including social media with intention to deceive any other person about COVID-19; the infection status of any person; any measure taken by the Government to address COVID019" is committing an offence.

description: The Republic of South Africa's Institute of Maritime Medicine (IMM) embarks on screening and information drives, as a "part of a bigger national campaign to get as many people possible screened and tested so that government can determine the full extent of the number of people infected by the virus" on April 01 2020.

description:
Republic of South Africa, policy effective from: March 26 2020 at 23h59 until April 16 2020 23h59.

SA is enforcing a 21-day mandatory quarantine for all South Africans, as well as any tourists and persons staying within the borders of the republic. "For the period of this Lockdown every person is confined to his or her place of residence (exceptions: for the purpose of performing an essencial service, obtaining an essential good or service, collecting a social grant, or seeking emergency, life-saving, or chronic medical attention)... and every gathering is prohibited (exception: funerals, max. 50 people in attendance)"

description: The Republic of South Africa announces the deployment of law enforcers made up of the South African Police Service (SAPS); the South African National Defence Force (SANDF), and metro police units […] to enforce the [lockdown] regulations" on March 23 2020.

The Republic of South Africa announces the deployment of "about 24 389 law enforcers made up of the South African Police Service (SAPS); the South African National Defence Force (SANDF), and metro police units [...] to enforce the [lockdown] regulations" on April 02 2020. UPDATE: The exact number was announced on April 02 2020

The Republic of South Africa announces the "Social Security Agency (SASSA) has also set aside over R400 million for social relief of distress through food parcels and vouchers to be rolled out on a larger scale" and "over 100,000 households across the country have been provided with food parcels, with further households being targeted through the Solidarity Fund and Department of Social Development’s Disaster Relief Fund" since the beginning of the lockdown on April 18 2020.

description: The Republic of South Africa's National Defence Force (SANDF) calls upon its "members from the Reserve Force to complement the already deployed SANDF in the fight against COVID-19 in line with the Natural Disaster Management Act of 2002" on March 28 2020
The Republic of South Africa announces the Debt Relief Finance Scheme for "businesses which are negatively affected, directly or indirectly, due to the Coronavirus pandemic" on March 31 2020.

description: The Republic of South Africa sets up a Tourism Relief Fund for affected businesses in the tourism sector to "provide once-off grant assistance to Small, Micro and Medium-sized businesses in the tourism value chain" on April 07 2020.

description: The Republic of South Africa announces measures to permit the "transportation of essential goods […] from warehousing sites to essential service providers" as well as to "ports of entry for the purposes of exporting" on April 17 2020.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Republic of South Africa announces that "Mining operations [as classified as an essencial service] must be conducted at a reduced capacity of not more than 50% during the period of lockdown, and thereafter at increasing capacity as determined by direction issued by the Cabinet member responsible for mineral resources and energy" on April 16 2020.
type_text: Economic Policy regarding conduct of mining operations
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Republic of South Africa announces measures to "ensure the continuous supply of energy and petroleum products to society as referred to in paragraph 6 of Part B of Annexure B- (a) collieries that supply Eskom must continue to operate at full capacity; and (b) refineries must operate at full capacity to avoid shortage of fuel, and such operations must include smelters, plants and furnaces" on April 16 2020.
type_text: Conduct and procedures for Critical Infrastructure and Essential Services: Energy sector
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Republic of South Africa's President meets with "social partners represented in the National Economic Development and Labour Council (NEDLAC) to discuss deepening cooperation as part of the national effort to combat the coronavirus pandemic" on April 17 2020.

description: The Republic of South Africa's President announces further steps in the fight against COVID-19: "Firstly, an extraordinary health budget to respond to coronavirus, secondly, the relief of hunger and social distress, Thirdly, support for companies and workers, Fourthly, the phased re-opening of the economy." on April 21 2020.

The Republic of South Africa invites "sectors and business organisations / trade unions and members of the public […] to submit comments on the schedule of services to be phased in as per the Covid-19 Risk Adjusted Strategy to be implemented with effect from 01 May 2020" on April 23 2020.

description: The Republic of South Africa's President Cyril Ramaphosa announces that with the downgrading of the Risk Adjusted Strategy from Level 4 to Level 3, "alcohol may be sold for home consumption only under strict conditions, on specified days and for limited hours" on May 24 2020.

As of June 1st, the government of South Africa fully opened routine health care services and continue to provide services with attention to childhood immunisation, contraceptive services, antenatal care, diagnosis and treatment of tuberculosis and HIV, management of chronic diseases and support for survivors of gender-based violence.

The Government of South Africa states that all manufacturing, mining, construction, financial services, professional and business services, information technology,
communications, government services, and media services will commence full reopening from 1 June.

The Republic of South Africa, from June 25, allows cinemas to re-open subject to
- a limitation of 50 persons or less
- sale of tickets through a booking system
- strict adherence to all health protocols and social distancing measures
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa prohibits gatherings on March 15, 2020, in which a gathering is defined as any assembly, concourse or procession of more than 100 persons wholly or partially in open air or in a building or premises.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa prohibits gatherings on March 15, 2020, in which a gathering is defined as any assembly, concourse or procession of more than 100 persons wholly or partially in open air or in a building or premises. UPDATE: On March 26, 2020 the Republic of South African went into Alert Level 5 lockdown, meaning no at all gatherings were permitted - with exceptions for funerals.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa announces all gatherings are banned, in which a gathering is any "assembly, concourse or procession" in a public or private place. There are exemptions for funerals, workplaces and buying goods and services - from May 1 to May 31, 2020 under Alert Level 4 restrictions.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: The Republic of South Africa allows gatherings under Alert Level 3 restrictions at "a faith-based institution, which is limited to 50 persons or less, depending on the size of the place of worship. Provided all health protocols and social distancing measures are being adhered to" from June 1 to August 17, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa, under Alert Level 3, allows "professional non-contact sports matches, which may only include players, match officials, journalists and medical and television crew" from June 1.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa, under Alert Level 3, prohibits all gatherings except those at a faith based institution, funerals, workplaces, agricultural auctions and a professional non-contact sports match - all of which are privy to their own restrictions. This is in place from June 1 to June 25 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: The Republic of South Africa, under Alert Level 3 from June 25 to August 17, 2020 prohibits all gatherings except at a "faith based institution, a funeral, a workplace, cinemas, theatres, casinos, an agricultural auction, sporting activities, museums, galleries, libraries and archives, personal care services and restaurants" all under adherence to health protocols and social distancing measures as provided by the Cabinet member responsible for health.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
The Republic of South Africa, from July 31 to August 17 2020, allows "sporting activities, inclusive of both professional non-contact and contact matches subject to 
-directions for sports matches issued by the Cabinet member responsible
- only journalists, radio, television crew, security personnel, emergency medical services and necessary employees are allowed at the venue
- only the required number of players, match officials, support staff and medical crew required are allowed at the venue
- no spectators allowed at the venue
- no international sport events are allowed"
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa, under Alert Level 3, allows "professional non-contact sports matches, which may only include players, match officials, journalists and medical and television crew" from June 1. UPDATE: On July 31 2020, contact sports are also allowed to commence, ending this policy and initiating a new one.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: The Republic of South Africa's Office of the Provincial Commissioner of the Northern Cape states that taxis are being "checked whether they operate during the right time frames, everyone walking around was checked whether he or she complying with the President’s instruction of staying at home" on March 29 2020.

description: The Republic of South Africa, under Alert Level 3, from June 1 2020 re-enforces that "a person must when in a public place, wear a cloth face mask or a homemade item that covers the nose and mouth, or another appropriate item to cover the nose and mouth".

description: The Republic of South Africa, under Alert Level 3, from June 1 2020 re-enforces that "a person must when in a public place, wear a cloth face mask or a homemade item that covers the nose and mouth, or another appropriate item to cover the nose and mouth". UPDATE: On July 12, 2020 an exception is made to this policy and it does not apply to "a person who undertakes vigorous exercise in a public place, provided that the person maintains a distance of at least three metres from any other person". This is in place until the end of Alert level 3, August 17.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
